elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Ca(NO3)2 or Ba(NO3)2 with aromatic carboxylate ligands afforded four new inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks, [Ca(PBDC)(H2O)3] n (1), [Ca(OBDC)(H2O)] n (2), [Ba5(OBDC)4(H2O)2(NO3)2] n (3), and [Ba3(BTC)2(H2O)4] n (4) (H2PBDC = terephthalic acid, H2OBDC = phthalic acid, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid). These compounds have been fully characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, satisfactory elemental analysis, IR spectra, and TG analysis. X-ray analysis shows that compound 1 features a one-dimensional chain (1D) structure with the I1O0 connectivity, both compound 2 and compound 3 feature a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure with the I1O1 connectivity, I2O0 connectivity, respectively, compound 4 features a three-dimensional (3D) framework with a rare I3O0 connectivity. Thermal stabilities and luminescent properties of compounds 1–4 and NLO property of compound 4 have also been investigated.

elements.content: Ever-increasing interests in the synthesis of hybrid inorganic–organic frameworks stems not only from their potential application in the areas of luminescence, semiconductors, storage materials, and magnetic materials, and so on, but also from their intriguing architectures and topologies. However, most of the research works so far are mainly focused on the incorporation of transition metal ions and rare-earth ions as coordination centers. Whereas relatively less attention has been paid to the alkaline earth metal-based compounds. Recently, the main group alkaline-earth metals, owing to their low polarizability and various coordination modes for the construction of polymer materials featuring robust structures and interesting properties, are receiving more and more research attention. Against this background, numerous alkaline earth metal-based coordination polymers have been constructed from the multifunctional carboxylate ligands. For instance, Leah N. Appelhans and his coworks reported a series of alkaline earth tartrates, in which the alkaline earth metal ions exhibit different phase behavior in the reactions with the three forms tartaric acid. Besides, heterometallic hybrid materials of Pb(II)-aromatic carboxylates doped with alkaline earth metal ions (Ca or Sr) have also been reported. In these complexes, the alkaline earth ions not only act as charge balance ions but also involved in the structure construction, which resulted in a series of distinct topological frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ever-increasing interests in the synthesis of hybrid inorganic-organic frameworks stems not only from their potential application in the areas of luminescence, semiconductors, storage materials, and magnetic materials, and so on, but also from their intriguing architectures and topologies. However, most of the research works so far are mainly focused on the incorporation of transition metal ions and rare-earth ions as coordination centers. Whereas relatively less attention has been paid to the alkaline earth metal-based compounds. Recently, the main group alkaline-earth metals, owing to their low polarizability and various coordination modes for the construction of polymer materials featuring robust structures and interesting properties, are receiving more and more research attention. Against this background, numerous alkaline earth metal-based coordination polymers have been constructed from the multifunctional carboxylate ligands. For instance, Leah N. Appelhans and his coworks reported a series of alkaline earth tartrates, in which the alkaline earth metal ions exhibit different phase behavior in the reactions with the three forms tartaric acid. Besides, heterometallic hybrid materials of Pb(II)-aromatic carboxylates doped with alkaline earth metal ions (Ca or Sr) have also been reported. In these complexes, the alkaline earth ions not only act as charge balance ions but also involved in the structure construction, which resulted in a series of distinct topological frameworks.

elements.content: On the other hand, extended inorganic hybrids with arrays of inorganic connectivity, M–X–M (M = metal, X = O, Cl, N, or S) remain less explored despite their peculiar magnetic, electronic, optical properties, which usually exist in metal oxides. The connectivity of extended hybrid framework can be described using I n O m notion. I n is the dimensionality of the inorganic connectivity (metal–oxygen–metal), O m is the dimensionality of the organic connectivity. The sum of n + m is the overall connectivty and must be less than or equal to 3. In recent years, some hybrid frameworks with diversity of connectivities, such as I0O3, I1O0, I1O1, I1O2 I2O0, and I2O1 have been reported. However, fabrication of an inorganic–organic hybrid compound with I3O0 connectivity remains a great challenge to chemists. Therefore, rational selection of metal ions with well-defined coordination geometries and organic polycarboxylate ligands will play a key role in synthesizing coordination polymers with desired inorganic connectivity and excellent properties. Comparing with transition metal ions, alkaline earth metal ions have relatively larger radius, and have high affinity for oxygen donors, which will provide unique opportunities for the formation of extended inorganic hybrids with rigid aromatic polycarboxylate ligand.

The connectivity of extended hybrid framework can be described using I n O m  notion. I n  is the dimensionality of the inorganic connectivity (metal-oxygen-metal), O m  is the dimensionality of the organic connectivity. The sum of n + m is the overall connectivty and must be less than or equal to 3. In recent years, some hybrid frameworks with diversity of connectivities, such as I0O3, I1O0, I1O1, I1O2 I2O0, and I2O1 have been reported. However, fabrication of an inorganic-organic hybrid compound with I3O0 connectivity remains a great challenge to chemists. Therefore, rational selection of metal ions with well-defined coordination geometries and organic polycarboxylate ligands will play a key role in synthesizing coordination polymers with desired inorganic connectivity and excellent properties. Comparing with transition metal ions, alkaline earth metal ions have relatively larger radius, and have high affinity for oxygen donors, which will provide unique opportunities for the formation of extended inorganic hybrids with rigid aromatic polycarboxylate ligand.

elements.content: In this work, we reported the synthesis and characterization of a series of Ca(II) or Ba(II) aromatic polycarboxylate hybrid frameworks, [Ca(PBDC)(H2O)3] n (1), [Ca(OBDC)(H2O)] n (2), [Ba5(OBDC)4(H2O)2(NO3)2] n (3), and [Ba3(BTC)2(H2O)4] n (4). Of particular interest is that the inorganic connectivity of the title compounds varies from 1D to 3D. To the best of our knowledge, compound 4 represents the first example of Ba(II)-aromatic tricarboxylate with extended 3D inorganic connectivity.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we reported the synthesis and characterization of a series of Ca(II) or Ba(II) aromatic polycarboxylate hybrid frameworks, [Ca(PBDC)(H2O)3] n  (1), [Ca(OBDC)(H2O)] n  (2), [Ba5(OBDC)4(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (3), and [Ba3(BTC)2(H2O)4] n  (4). Of particular interest is that the inorganic connectivity of the title compounds varies from 1D to 3D. To the best of our knowledge, compound 4 represents the first example of Ba(II)-aromatic tricarboxylate with extended 3D inorganic connectivity.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in 23 mL polytetrafluoroethylene lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses were performed on an EA1110 CHNS–0 CE elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT–IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Powder X–ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. The fluorescence spectra were measured on powder samples at room temperature using an Edinburgh FLS920 TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer. TGA analyses were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in 23 mL polytetrafluoroethylene lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. Elemental analyses were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. The fluorescence spectra were measured on powder samples at room temperature using an Edinburgh FLS920 TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer. TGA analyses were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.048 g, 0.20 mmol), and terephthalic acid (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon linear; 2 mL of DMF and 8 mL of H2O were then added. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and then the mixture was sealed in a Parr autolave and kept at 110 °C for four days. After being slowly cooled to the room temperature, colorless prism crystals of 1 were isolated. Yield: 57% based on Ca. Anal. Calcd for C8H10CaO7 (258.24): C, 37.17; H, 3.87%. Found: C, 37.15; H, 3.89%. IR data (KBr pellet): 3434 (m), 3134 (w), 1655 (s), 1497 (s), 1437 (w), 1376 (m), 1282 (m), 1249 (w), 1197 (w), 1145 (s), 1107 (m), 1060 (m), 1014 (w), 986 (m), 670 (m), 663 (s).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1–4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed on a computer-controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λMo/Kα = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anistropically, and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. However, the oxygen-bounded hydrogen atoms were located from difference peaks and kept in that position with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.5 times that of respective oxygen atoms. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of 1–4 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1–S4.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of 1-4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed on a computer-controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo/Kα radiation (λMo/Kα = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anistropically, and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. However, the oxygen-bounded hydrogen atoms were located from difference peaks and kept in that position with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.5 times that of respective oxygen atoms. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of 1-4 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in  Table S1-S4.

Solvothermal method was employed in this work rather than conventional solution method. Solvothermal reactions, generally carried out in Teflon bombs under autogenous pressure, not only can enhance the solubility of the organic ligand, but also can enhance the reaction pressure in favor of molecular self-assembly. In view of high affinity for oxygen donors, especially for water molecules, alkaline earth metal ions (Ca or Ba) and aromatic polycarboxylate ligand mixed in DMF/H2O system were used in this work to prepare variety of inorganic–organic hybrids with varied inorganic connectivity. It was found that compound 1 was a 1D chain structure with 1D inorganic Ca–O–Ca connectivity because PBDC ligand only use its one carboxylate group to coordinate to Ca(II) ions. When OBDC ligand was used instead of PBDC, compound 2, featuring a 2D layer structure, was obtained with 1D inorganic Ca–O–Ca connectivity. Different from 1, each OBDC ligand use its two carboxylate groups to connect two different Ca–O–Ca chains, resulted in the final 2D layer structure. Ba(II) has larger radius than Ca(II), and can have a higher coordination number. When Ba(II) ions was used instead of Ca(II), compound 3, also featuring a 2D layer structure, was obtained with 2D inorganic Ba–O–Ba connectivity because of the higher coordination number of Ba(II) ion. BTC ligand has three carboxylate groups, and may connect metal centers into a 3D framework. Therefore, when BTC ligand was used instead of OBDC, expectedly a new 3D hybrid framework, 4, was obtained, which features a rare 3D inorganic Ba–O–Ba connectivity. These observations indicate that exploiting aromatic polycarboxylate ligand with different carboxylate groups and alkaline earth metal ions with different radius may construct a series of coordination polymers with varied inorganic M–O–M connectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Solvothermal method was employed in this work rather than conventional solution method. Solvothermal reactions, generally carried out in Teflon bombs under autogenous pressure, not only can enhance the solubility of the organic ligand, but also can enhance the reaction pressure in favor of molecular self-assembly. In view of high affinity for oxygen donors, especially for water molecules, alkaline earth metal ions (Ca or Ba) and aromatic polycarboxylate ligand mixed in DMF/H2O system were used in this work to prepare variety of inorganic-organic hybrids with varied inorganic connectivity. It was found that compound 1 was a 1D chain structure with 1D inorganic Ca-O-Ca connectivity because PBDC ligand only use its one carboxylate group to coordinate to Ca(II) ions. When OBDC ligand was used instead of PBDC, compound 2, featuring a 2D layer structure, was obtained with 1D inorganic Ca-O-Ca connectivity. Different from 1, each OBDC ligand use its two carboxylate groups to connect two different Ca-O-Ca chains, resulted in the final 2D layer structure. Ba(II) has larger radius than Ca(II), and can have a higher coordination number. When Ba(II) ions was used instead of Ca(II), compound 3, also featuring a 2D layer structure, was obtained with 2D inorganic Ba-O-Ba connectivity because of the higher coordination number of Ba(II) ion. BTC ligand has three carboxylate groups, and may connect metal centers into a 3D framework. Therefore, when BTC ligand was used instead of OBDC, expectedly a new 3D hybrid framework, 4, was obtained, which features a rare 3D inorganic Ba-O-Ba connectivity. These observations indicate that exploiting aromatic polycarboxylate ligand with different carboxylate groups and alkaline earth metal ions with different radius may construct a series of coordination polymers with varied inorganic M-O-M connectivity.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographical analysis performed on compound 1 reveals an 1D chain structure. As depicted in Figure a, one crystallographically independent Ca(II) cation, one PBDC ligand and three coordinated water molecules constitute the fundamental unit of 1. Each Ca(II) ion is ligated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different PBDC ligands and four coordinated water molecules, furnishing a distorted {CaO8} bicap octahedral geometry. The Ca–O distances are in the range of 2.349(3)–2.633(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported Ca(II)-carboxylates. Among the two carboxyl groups of PBDC, one bridges and chelates three Ca(II) ions, the other does not participate in coordinating to Ca(II) ions. Therefore, PBDC ligand connects three Ca(II) cations with a μ3-(η2-O, O′),O,O′ coordination mode. It is note that each {CaO8} polyhedron shares two faces with two neighboring ones, and extends into a 1D inorganic Ca–O–Ca chain along crystallographical c axis (Figure b). The uncoordinated carboxylate groups decorated on both sides of the 1D chain (Figure c). Therefore, the final 1D chain structure of 1 can be classified as I1O0 type. Owing to the existence of exposed carboxylate groups and coordinated water molecules, significant hydrogen bond interactions among the adjacent chains finally resulted in a 3D supramolecular framework ( Figure S1). The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in Table S5. Although Ca-based terephthalate, [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] (H2BDC = terephthalic acid) have been reported before, it is a three-dimensional opened framework based on 1D Ca–O–Ca chains, and can be classified as I1O2 type.

1D Ca-O-Ca Connectivity in [Ca(PBDC)(H2O)3] n  (1)

X-ray crystallographical analysis performed on compound 1 reveals an 1D chain structure. As depicted in Figure a, one crystallographically independent Ca(II) cation, one PBDC ligand and three coordinated water molecules constitute the fundamental unit of 1. Each Ca(II) ion is ligated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different PBDC ligands and four coordinated water molecules, furnishing a distorted {CaO8} bicap octahedral geometry. The Ca-O distances are in the range of 2.349(3)-2.633(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported Ca(II)-carboxylates. Among the two carboxyl groups of PBDC, one bridges and chelates three Ca(II) ions, the other does not participate in coordinating to Ca(II) ions. Therefore, PBDC ligand connects three Ca(II) cations with a μ3-(η2-O, O'),O,O' coordination mode. It is note that each {CaO8} polyhedron shares two faces with two neighboring ones, and extends into a 1D inorganic Ca-O-Ca chain along crystallographical c axis (Figure b). The uncoordinated carboxylate groups decorated on both sides of the 1D chain (Figure c). Therefore, the final 1D chain structure of 1 can be classified as I1O0 type. Owing to the existence of exposed carboxylate groups and coordinated water molecules, significant hydrogen bond interactions among the adjacent chains finally resulted in a 3D supramolecular framework ( Figure S1). The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in  Table S5. Although Ca-based terephthalate, [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] (H2BDC = terephthalic acid) have been reported before, it is a three-dimensional opened framework based on 1D Ca-O-Ca chains, and can be classified as I1O2 type.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 is a 2D layer structure. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one crystallographically independent Ca(II) ion, one OBDC ligand and one terminal coordinated water molecule. Different from 1, each Ca(II) ion in 2 is located in the center of a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid with five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O2a, O3a, and O1c) from three different OBDC ligands at the equatorial plane, one aqua ligand (O1w) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O4b) from another OBDC ligand at the two remaining apical positions (Figure a). The average Ca–O distance is 2.400 Å, which is also in the normal range. The OBDC ligand connects four different Ca(II) ions with a μ4-(η2-O′,O″),(η2-O″,O‴),O,O‴ coordination mode, which is reported for the first time. Different from 1, each {CaO7} polyhedron in 2 shares two edges with two neighboring ones, and also extends into a 1D inorganic Ca–O–Ca chain along crystallographical b axis (Figure.b). Remarkably, each OBDC ligand links two individual Ca–O–Ca chains, and all of the 1D Ca–O–Ca inorganic chains are connected together by the OBDC ligands to form the final 2D layer structure with the I1O1 connectivity (Figure c). On the basis of our extensive search using the Cambridge Structural Database, 2 is the first Ca-based phthalate. Although Ca-based compounds based on the derivative of phthalate acid have been reported before, it is a 1D chain structure with I0O1 connectivity.

The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one crystallographically independent Ca(II) ion, one OBDC ligand and one terminal coordinated water molecule. Different from 1, each Ca(II) ion in 2 is located in the center of a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid with five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O2a, O3a, and O1c) from three different OBDC ligands at the equatorial plane, one aqua ligand (O1w) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O4b) from another OBDC ligand at the two remaining apical positions (Figure a). The OBDC ligand connects four different Ca(II) ions with a μ4-(η2-O',O"),(η2-O",O‴),O,O‴ coordination mode, which is reported for the first time. Different from 1, each {CaO7} polyhedron in 2 shares two edges with two neighboring ones, and also extends into a 1D inorganic Ca-O-Ca chain along crystallographical b axis (Figure.b). Remarkably, each OBDC ligand links two individual Ca-O-Ca chains, and all of the 1D Ca-O-Ca inorganic chains are connected together by the OBDC ligands to form the final 2D layer structure with the I1O1 connectivity (Figure c). elements.content: Compound 3 also features a 2D layer framework. Interestingly, it contains a 2D Ba–O–Ba inorganic layer with the OBDC ligands and nitrate ions residing on both sides of the inorganic layer, so the structure of 3 should be classified as I2O0 type. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 3 contains two and a half crystallographically independent Ba(II) ions, two independent OBDC ligands, one aqua ligand, as well as one coordinated nitrate ion. As shown in Figure a, Ba1 is eight-coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6, O4c, O4g, O5f, O6f, O7d, and O7e) from six individual OBDC ligands, exhibiting a slightly distorted bicap octahedral geometry. Both Ba2 and Ba3 adopt a slightly distorted bicap triagular prism. However, the coordination environments around them (Ba2 and Ba3) are different. Ba2 is coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1f, O1g, O3g, O8e, O2d, and o2d) from five different OBDC ligands, one nitrate oxygen atoms (O9) and one terminal aqua ligand (O1w). Ba3 is coordinated by seven carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O6, O7, O3b, O4c, O6d, and O8d) from five individual OBDC ligands and one nitrate oxygen atom (O9a). Each {Ba1O8} polyhedron shares four edges and one corner with five {BaO8} polyhedrons. Each {Ba2O8} polyhedron shares two edges and three corners with five neighboring {BaO8} polyhedrons. Each {Ba3O8} polyhedron shares four edges and two corners with six neighboring {BaO8} polyhedrons. Then, these connectivities link the polyhedrons into a 2D inorganic Ba–O–Ba layer (Figure b), which is decorated by the OBDC ligands and nitrate anions on both sides. Notably, there are two different rings in this inorganic layer: 3- and 4-membered rings (Figure b). Two crystallographically independent OBDC ligands adopt different coordination modes: μ5-(η2-O′,O″),O,O′,O,″O‴ and μ6-(η2-O′,O″),O,O,O″,O‴,O‴. To the best of our knowledge, these two kinds of coordination modes have not been reported before, and further enriched the coordination chemistry of OBDC ligand. In addition, nitrate ion in 3 not only acts as charge balance ion but also involves in the structure construction with its one oxygen atom connecting two Ba(II) ions. In previously reported nitrate ion-containing compounds, nitrate ion either acts as a template or mainly adopts four coordination modes: (i) chelating mode connecting one metal center (ii) monodentate mode connecting one metal center (iii) tridentate mode connecting three metal centers (iv) chelating and bridging mode connecting two metal centers, However, such coordination mode in 3 has rarely been reported before. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, 3 is the first Ba-based phthalate. Although Ba-based carboxylates have been largely reported before, such polymers featuring a 2D inorganic Ba–O–Ba connectivity are rarely reported.

2D Ba-O-Ba Connectivity in [Ba5(OBDC)4(H2O)2(NO3)2] n  (3)

Compound 3 also features a 2D layer framework. Interestingly, it contains a 2D Ba-O-Ba inorganic layer with the OBDC ligands and nitrate ions residing on both sides of the inorganic layer, so the structure of 3 should be classified as I2O0 type. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 3 contains two and a half crystallographically independent Ba(II) ions, two independent OBDC ligands, one aqua ligand, as well as one coordinated nitrate ion. As shown in Figure a, Ba1 is eight-coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6, O4c, O4g, O5f, O6f, O7d, and O7e) from six individual OBDC ligands, exhibiting a slightly distorted bicap octahedral geometry. Both Ba2 and Ba3 adopt a slightly distorted bicap triagular prism. However, the coordination environments around them (Ba2 and Ba3) are different. Ba2 is coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1f, O1g, O3g, O8e, O2d, and o2d) from five different OBDC ligands, one nitrate oxygen atoms (O9) and one terminal aqua ligand (O1w). Ba3 is coordinated by seven carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O6, O7, O3b, O4c, O6d, and O8d) from five individual OBDC ligands and one nitrate oxygen atom (O9a). Each {Ba1O8} polyhedron shares four edges and one corner with five {BaO8} polyhedrons. Each {Ba2O8} polyhedron shares two edges and three corners with five neighboring {BaO8} polyhedrons. Each {Ba3O8} polyhedron shares four edges and two corners with six neighboring {BaO8} polyhedrons. Then, these connectivities link the polyhedrons into a 2D inorganic Ba-O-Ba layer (Figure b), which is decorated by the OBDC ligands and nitrate anions on both sides. Notably, there are two different rings in this inorganic layer: 3- and 4-membered rings (Figure b). Two crystallographically independent OBDC ligands adopt different coordination modes: μ5-(η2-O',O"),O,O',O,"O‴ and μ6-(η2-O',O"),O,O,O",O‴,O‴. To the best of our knowledge, these two kinds of coordination modes have not been reported before, and further enriched the coordination chemistry of OBDC ligand. In addition, nitrate ion in 3 not only acts as charge balance ion but also involves in the structure construction with its one oxygen atom connecting two Ba(II) ions. In previously reported nitrate ion-containing compounds, nitrate ion either acts as a template or mainly adopts four coordination modes: (i) chelating mode connecting one metal center (ii) monodentate mode connecting one metal center (iii) tridentate mode connecting three metal centers (iv) chelating and bridging mode connecting two metal centers, However, such coordination mode in 3 has rarely been reported before. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, 3 is the first Ba-based phthalate. Although Ba-based carboxylates have been largely reported before, such polymers featuring a 2D inorganic Ba-O-Ba connectivity are rarely reported.

elements.content: Compound 4 features a rare 3D inorganic Ba–O–Ba framework, which is first found in Ba(II)-aromatic carboxylates. Three crystallographically independent Ba(II) ions, two BTC ligands and four coordinated water molecules constitute the fundamental unit of 4. As shown in Figure a, Ba1 is coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O10, O6d, and O9e) from four individual BTC ligands and three terminal aqua ligands (O1w, O3w, and O4w), forming a slightly distorted {Ba1O7} monocap triangular prism. Ba2 is eight-coordinated with a severely distorted {Ba2O8} square antiprismatic geomerty provided by seven carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3b, O5d, O6d, O7c, and O11e) from five different BTC ligands and one terminal aqua ligand (O2w). while Ba3 is nine-coordinated with the coordination sites occupied by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from five different BTC ligands and one terminal aqua ligand, furnishing a severely distorted {Ba3O9} monocap square antiprismatic geometry. According to the coordination modes, BTC ligands in 4 can be divided into two kinds with one in μ7-(η2-O,O′),(η2-O″,O‴),O,O‴,O⁗,O′′′′′,O′′′′′ and one in μ7-(η2-O,O′),O,O″,O‴,O⁗,O′′′′′,O′′′′′ mode. Although numerous coordination polymers based on BTC ligands have been investigated, the above-mentioned coordination modes of BTC ligand have never been reported before, which further enriched the coordination chemistry of BTC ligand. Each {Ba1O7} polyhedron shares two edges with {Ba2O8} and {Ba3O9}, and one corner with {Ba3O9}. Each {Ba2O8} polyhedron shares two edges with {Ba3O9} and {Ba1O7}, and one corner with {Ba3O9}. Each {Ba3O9} polyhedron share two edges with {Ba1O7} and {Ba2O8}, and two corners with {Ba1O7} and {Ba2O8}. As shown in Figure b, the accumulating of these polyhedrons resulted in the final 3D inorganic Ba–O–Ba framework. The most fascinating structural feature of this inorganic skeleton is the presence of the 1D channels with 13-membered rings along crystallographical a axis. These 1D channels are occupied by the BTC ligands (Figure c). So the structure of 4 should be classified as I3O0 type. On the basis of extensive search using the Cambridge Structural Database, only one Ba-based tartrate with I3O0 connectivity has been reported before, such connectivity based on rigid aromatic polycarboxylate, up to nom, is rarely reported.
elements.clean_text:
3D Ba-O-Ba Connectivity in [Ba3(BTC)2(H2O)4] n  (4)

Compound 4 features a rare 3D inorganic Ba-O-Ba framework, which is first found in Ba(II)-aromatic carboxylates. Three crystallographically independent Ba(II) ions, two BTC ligands and four coordinated water molecules constitute the fundamental unit of 4. As shown in Figure a, Ba1 is coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O10, O6d, and O9e) from four individual BTC ligands and three terminal aqua ligands (O1w, O3w, and O4w), forming a slightly distorted {Ba1O7} monocap triangular prism. Ba2 is eight-coordinated with a severely distorted {Ba2O8} square antiprismatic geomerty provided by seven carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3b, O5d, O6d, O7c, and O11e) from five different BTC ligands and one terminal aqua ligand (O2w). while Ba3 is nine-coordinated with the coordination sites occupied by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from five different BTC ligands and one terminal aqua ligand, furnishing a severely distorted {Ba3O9} monocap square antiprismatic geometry. According to the coordination modes, BTC ligands in 4 can be divided into two kinds with one in μ7-(η2-O,O'),(η2-O",O‴),O,O‴,O⁗,O''''',O''''' and one in μ7-(η2-O,O'),O,O",O‴,O⁗,O''''',O''''' mode. Although numerous coordination polymers based on BTC ligands have been investigated, the above-mentioned coordination modes of BTC ligand have never been reported before, which further enriched the coordination chemistry of BTC ligand. Each {Ba1O7} polyhedron shares two edges with {Ba2O8} and {Ba3O9}, and one corner with {Ba3O9}. Each {Ba2O8} polyhedron shares two edges with {Ba3O9} and {Ba1O7}, and one corner with {Ba3O9}. Each {Ba3O9} polyhedron share two edges with {Ba1O7} and {Ba2O8}, and two corners with {Ba1O7} and {Ba2O8}. As shown in Figure b, the accumulating of these polyhedrons resulted in the final 3D inorganic Ba-O-Ba framework. The most fascinating structural feature of this inorganic skeleton is the presence of the 1D channels with 13-membered rings along crystallographical a axis. These 1D channels are occupied by the BTC ligands (Figure c). So the structure of 4 should be classified as I3O0 type. On the basis of extensive search using the Cambridge Structural Database, only one Ba-based tartrate with I3O0 connectivity has been reported before, such connectivity based on rigid aromatic polycarboxylate, up to nom, is rarely reported.

elements.content: The simulated and experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1–4 have been shown in Figure S2–S5. Their peak positions correspond well with the results simulated from the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples. The difference in intensities between the simulated and experimental patterns may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples during the collection of the experimental PXRD data.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD Patterns and Thermal Properties

The simulated and experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1-4 have been shown in  Figure S2-S5. Their peak positions correspond well with the results simulated from the single crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples. The difference in intensities between the simulated and experimental patterns may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples during the collection of the experimental PXRD data.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the thermal stabilities of the four compounds, TG analysis was performed on polycrystalline samples under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range of 30–900 °C. The TGA curve (Figure a) of 1 shows two main weight losses. The first one occurs in the temperature range of 70–130 °C corresponding to the release of three coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (21.55%) is in agreement with the calculated one (20.91%). The dehydrated sample can be stable up to 510 °C, then the second weight loss occurs, indicating that the whole framework collapse because of the decomposition of the PBDC ligand. For compound 2, the coordinated water molecules escaped from the host framework over the range of 137–208 °C with observed weight loss of 8.28% (Calcd 8.10%). Then the dehydrated sample can be stable up to 416 °C. Upon heating beyond 416 °C, the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the OBDC ligand (Figure b). For 3, there is a continuously weight loss of 1.97% in the temperature range of 116–455 °C, corresponding to the release of the coordinated water molecules (Calcd 2.39%), Then a dramatically weight loss occurs indicating the decomposition of the whole framework (Figure c). For 4, the release of four coordinated water molecules per formula unit occurs in the range of 75–195 °C, the observed weight loss of 8.27% is in agreement with the calculated one (8.02%). The dehydrated sample can be stable up to 500 °C, followed by a dramatically collapse of the framework due to the decomposition of the BTC ligand (Figure d).

elements.content: The luminescent properties of 1–4 have been investigated in the solid-state at room temperature. And in order to understand these emission bands, we have also examined the luminescent properties of the free ligand (H2PBDC, H2OBDC, and H3BTC). The free ligands emit strong fluorescence centered at 447 nm (λex = 349 nm) for H2PBDC, 433 nm (λex = 329 nm) for H2OBDC, 448 nm (λex = 331 nm) for H3BTC, respectively. The luminescent behavior of free ligands can be probably assigned to π or n to π* orbital transitions. For the compounds, the emission bands are 445 nm (λex = 348 nm) for 1, 448 nm (λex = 334 nm) for 2, 446 nm (λex = 314 nm) for 3, 442 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 4, respectively. It is noteworthy that the emission bands of the compounds are similar to that of corresponding free ligands. Therefore, these emission bands are neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), and can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emission. In addition, the emit light of 1 red-shifted by approximate 57 nm comparing with another PBDC-based Ca(II) compound, [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] n (5, H2BDC = terephthalic acid), which may be due to the binding degree of organic ligand to Ca ions. In 1, PBDC ligand only use one carboxylate group coordinating to Ca(II) centers, leaving another carboxylate group exposed, while in 5, PBDC ligand use its two carboxylate groups binding to Ca(II) centers, which may resulted in a more rigid structure of ligand than 1. The corresponding decay lifetimes of compounds 1–4 are 0.1230, 0.1321, 0.1331, and 0.2461 ns, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the acentric space group Pna21. Hence, its second-order NLO property is worthy studying. Approximate estimation was carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output λ = 532 nm) produced by the powder sample of compound 4 is about 1.2 times of that produced by a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder, indicating that compound 4 has SHG effect that is stronger than that of KDP, making it a potential candidate as a new SHG material.
elements.clean_text:
Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) Measurement

Compound 4 crystallizes in the acentric space group Pna21. Hence, its second-order NLO property is worthy studying. Approximate estimation was carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output λ = 532 nm) produced by the powder sample of compound 4 is about 1.2 times of that produced by a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder, indicating that compound 4 has SHG effect that is stronger than that of KDP, making it a potential candidate as a new SHG material.

elements.content: A series of Ca(II) or Ba(II) inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks based on aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared and characterized, in which the inorganic connectivity varies from 1D to 3D. Compound 1 is a 1D chain structure with 1D Ca–O–Ca connectivity. Compound 2 and 3 are 2D layer structure with 1D Ca–O–Ca linkage for 2, 2D Ba–O–Ba linkage for 3. Compound 4 possess a 3D framework with a rare 3D extended Ba–O–Ba linkage, which represents the first example of Ba(II)-aromatic tricarboxylate. Furthermore, compounds 1–4 exhibit strong ligand-centered fluorescence at room temperature in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of Ca(II) or Ba(II) inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks based on aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared and characterized, in which the inorganic connectivity varies from 1D to 3D. Compound 1 is a 1D chain structure with 1D Ca-O-Ca connectivity. Compound 2 and 3 are 2D layer structure with 1D Ca-O-Ca linkage for 2, 2D Ba-O-Ba linkage for 3. Compound 4 possess a 3D framework with a rare 3D extended Ba-O-Ba linkage, which represents the first example of Ba(II)-aromatic tricarboxylate. Furthermore, compounds 1-4 exhibit strong ligand-centered fluorescence at room temperature in the solid state.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.048 g, 0.20 mmol), and terephthalic acid (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon linear; 2 mL of DMF and 8 mL of H2O were then added. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, and then the mixture was sealed in a Parr autolave and kept at 110 °C for four days. After being slowly cooled to the room temperature, colorless prism crystals of 1 were isolated. Yield: 57% based on Ca. Anal. Calcd for C8H10CaO7 (258.24): C, 37.17; H, 3.87%. Found: C, 37.15; H, 3.89%. IR data (KBr pellet): 3434 (m), 3134 (w), 1655 (s), 1497 (s), 1437 (w), 1376 (m), 1282 (m), 1249 (w), 1197 (w), 1145 (s), 1107 (m), 1060 (m), 1014 (w), 986 (m), 670 (m), 663 (s).

cln_elements.content:
In order to evaluate the thermal stabilities of the four compounds, TG analysis was performed on polycrystalline samples under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range of 30–900 °C. The TGA curve (Figure a) of 1 shows two main weight losses. The first one occurs in the temperature range of 70–130 °C corresponding to the release of three coordinated water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (21.55%) is in agreement with the calculated one (20.91%). The dehydrated sample can be stable up to 510 °C, then the second weight loss occurs, indicating that the whole framework collapse because of the decomposition of the PBDC ligand. For compound 2, the coordinated water molecules escaped from the host framework over the range of 137–208 °C with observed weight loss of 8.28% (Calcd 8.10%). Then the dehydrated sample can be stable up to 416 °C. Upon heating beyond 416 °C, the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the OBDC ligand (Figure b). For 3, there is a continuously weight loss of 1.97% in the temperature range of 116–455 °C, corresponding to the release of the coordinated water molecules (Calcd 2.39%), Then a dramatically weight loss occurs indicating the decomposition of the whole framework (Figure c). For 4, the release of four coordinated water molecules per formula unit occurs in the range of 75–195 °C, the observed weight loss of 8.27% is in agreement with the calculated one (8.02%). The dehydrated sample can be stable up to 500 °C, followed by a dramatically collapse of the framework due to the decomposition of the BTC ligand (Figure d).

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of 1–4 have been investigated in the solid-state at room temperature. And in order to understand these emission bands, we have also examined the luminescent properties of the free ligand (H2PBDC, H2OBDC, and H3BTC). The free ligands emit strong fluorescence centered at 447 nm (λex = 349 nm) for H2PBDC, 433 nm (λex = 329 nm) for H2OBDC, 448 nm (λex = 331 nm) for H3BTC, respectively. The luminescent behavior of free ligands can be probably assigned to π or n to π* orbital transitions. For the compounds, the emission bands are 445 nm (λex = 348 nm) for 1, 448 nm (λex = 334 nm) for 2, 446 nm (λex = 314 nm) for 3, 442 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 4, respectively. It is noteworthy that the emission bands of the compounds are similar to that of corresponding free ligands. Therefore, these emission bands are neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), and can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emission. In addition, the emit light of 1 red-shifted by approximate 57 nm comparing with another PBDC-based Ca(II) compound, [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] n (5, H2BDC = terephthalic acid), which may be due to the binding degree of organic ligand to Ca ions. In 1, PBDC ligand only use one carboxylate group coordinating to Ca(II) centers, leaving another carboxylate group exposed, while in 5, PBDC ligand use its two carboxylate groups binding to Ca(II) centers, which may resulted in a more rigid structure of ligand than 1. The corresponding decay lifetimes of compounds 1–4 are 0.1230, 0.1321, 0.1331, and 0.2461 ns, respectively.
